messageBody:
Just a couple thoughts...

- Before refactoring, write a test case to ensure that refactoring
doesn't break anything.

- Before adding a new feature, write a test case for it, then implement
the feature (a la test first design).

- If you find that you're using System.out.println() as a debugging
aid, write a test case instead.

- If you find a bug, write a test case and then fix the bug. When the
test case passes, you've fixed the bug.

In general, I'd suggest building up your test suite incrementally as
existing code is refactored or new code is added, always keeping the
cost-benefit analysis in check.

Mike
